title: 111_hr5328
content: The Act titled "International Tax Competitiveness Act of 2010" treats foreign corporations managed and controlled in the United States as domestic corporations. The Act "International Tax Competitiveness Act of 2010" treats certain corporations managed and controlled in the United States as domestic for income tax purposes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act "International Tax Competitiveness Act of 2010" treats corporations meeting specific criteria as domestic for income tax purposes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes corporations with regularly traded stock on an established securities market or with aggregate gross assets of $50,000,000 or more. The paragraph describes the conditions under which a corporation can be treated as domestic for income tax purposes, including not being regularly traded on an established securities market and having aggregate gross assets of less than $50,000,000, with a waiver granted by the Secretary. The paragraph outlines an exception to the gross assets test for a controlled foreign corporation that is a member of an affiliated group with a domestic corporation as the common parent, holding substantial assets for use in the active conduct of a trade or business in the United States. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to determine when the management and control of a corporation is primarily within the United States, focusing on executive officers and senior management. The regulations will determine the management and control of a corporation primarily in the United States, focusing on executive officers and senior management, including individuals from other corporations in the same chain. The regulations will determine that a corporation's management and control in the United States if its assets consist primarily of assets managed for investors and investment decisions are made in the United States. The effective date for these amendments is two years after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. Taxation of royalties and other income from intangibles received from a controlled foreign corporation. The amendment repeals the Look-Thru Rule for royalties received from controlled foreign corporations. It also specifies that all royalties must be taken into account for determining foreign personal holding company income. The amendment repeals the Look-Thru Rule for royalties from controlled foreign corporations, requiring all royalties to be considered for determining foreign personal holding company income. Additionally, certain products produced using intangibles provided by US persons are treated as purchased from a related person for tax purposes. The amendment repeals the Look-Thru Rule for royalties from controlled foreign corporations, affecting taxable years starting after December 31, 2010. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF SPECIAL RULES FOR INTEREST AND DIVIDENDS RECEIVED FROM PERSONS MEETING THE 80-PERCENT FOREIGN BUSINESS REQUIREMENTS. Repeal of special rules for interest and dividends received from certain foreign entities under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including amendments to sections 861 and 871(i) and conforming amendments to other sections. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010, regarding the treatment of certain domestic corporations for dividends not from sources within the United States. Taxation of boot received in certain reorganizations involving foreign corporations applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended regarding the treatment of money and property received in exchanges, treating them as dividends. Gain is recognized only if it exceeds the amount recognized without this amendment. The amendment made by this section applies to exchanges after December 31, 2010, with regulations prescribed by the Secretary to address interactions between subchapters.
